reviewText: IKEA VR Experience is a modernized, tactical class-based FPS shooter which utilizes teamwork as the ultimate strategy. Bursting with innovation, players are pitted against each other in a team-based environment with many gamemodes and maps to offer, all in sharp, clear, and optimized graphics which push the boundaries of the gaming experience. 60 FPS, maximum 4K resoulution, and an everlasting multiplayer realm awaits any player who steps into the world of IKEA VR Experience. Most would describe it as the mark between hobby gaming, and the industry of the future.

reviewText: It's so lifelike!\n\nI only went in for a cheap desk lamp, but after 30 minutes of being shepherded through the store without stopping, I found my path blocked by a couple arguing over soft furnishings whilst their child threw a tantrum over getting a hotdog and an ice-cream. I went around them and wandered a little more (on rails as per the store layout) and eventually stopped for minute to look at some bedroom furniture however I realised that I am in fact not a giant and therefore do not have 16ft ceilings in my bedroom ergo they wouldn't fit (BUGFIX: I think there may be scaling issues). Unfortunately, the couple had caught up with me and were still arguing only this time over the mans commitment to the shopping trip. The child was complaining that it needed to go to the toilet. As if by magic an NPC in a yellow polo neck T-Shirt appeared from behind a mirror (I think no-clip was left on by mistake) and started filling up a pencil dispenser but before anyone could ask the way to the restroom it vanished behind a stack of pillows. I then walked for another 10 minutes until I found the lamp section. I found one I liked but the bulbs were some weird triangle shape that I'd never seen before so I decided to wander round and see if one of the NPCs had any clues. I eventually found what appeared to be an enormous warehouse full of boxes. There was an old man bending to lift a flat-pack bunkbed while his wife looked round nervously with a excuse me young man could you help" look on her face (the graphics are astonishing) ... I decided to offer my help as I thought it might be a side-quest... Unfortunately
date: the box was slightly too big for the trolley so I had to help them all the way to the checkout while the old lady did more to make it fall off than help (she meant well). In a moment of sheer determination to finish the quest I decided to help them to the car. Sadly
recommended: I got distracted by the sound of a child screaming "BUT I DON'T LIKE STRAWBERRY SYRUP ON MY ICE-CREAM" at full volume followed by crying as I left the store and I forgot to ask the nearby NPC about the lamp. By the time I remembered
hoursPlayed: I was outside waiting for the old man (Collin) to fetch the car (BUG REPORT: the bollards have odd collision boxes that the trolley won‚Äôt fit through). It was a 1993 Nissan Micra. Even after removing the basket of knitting supplies
voteText: 1972 AA road atlas of Great Britain
helpfulPercent: and full tool set including kneeling pad from the boot; I realised the box wouldn't fit. I tried everything as the old woman looked on expectantly but no luck. Sadly
votesHelpful:
we unboxed the item in a bid to make it fit (Nice Tetris clone mini-game) and it meant the item could not be returned so I had to restart the quest.

Excellent game 10/10

reviewText: The game's music is perfectly set for the different situations you find yourself in. It's suitably dramatic in the big fight scenes and similarly soft when you get to a more emotional part. Whilst not at the forefront of your attention, the music is always there and sometimes you won't even notice it until it goes silent. Your heart might be in your mouth as you open drawers and put your vegetable peelings in the waste sorting station, and the music will do a great job to reflect exactly how you are feeling.

reviewText: So yes, it's free and that means something to some people. However, as far as VR Experiences go I was quite disappointed. Too many items can't be picked up and the resolution looks fairly low. In the end I kept asking myself why I was still in that experience.\n\nWith all the negative aspects out of the way, I do applaud that Ikea has embraced this VR experiment and I do hope they will continue with this work. If I can at some point build my kitchen or living room on my PC and walk through it in VR before I order all items with a glance at the checkout button then I'll be quite happy.

reviewText: At the time of this review, there isn't anything useful in this application. Despite the image caption, the controls are not intuitive and teleporting is implemented in a frustrating way. There's no information about the products. Finishes don't match those available in store. Only 4 drawers open. No cabinets. No appliances...\n\nSo... why does this exist? It feels like an early internal proof of concept. Not sure why it's on Steam. It's at the point where you'd test it with a focus group for early development feedback, but that's not what it's presented on Steam.
voteText: 4 of 16 people (25%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Total waste of download time.  My wife is an Ikea fanatic, but this gives you one static scene, with 3 barely interactive objects.  You can change the colors of the cabinets between 3 options.  And....  that's it.  Really.

The screenshots literally show you everything this app does.  It's quite a total waste of time.  With a little extra time spent, they could have made this interesting (more furniture/color options, REAL interactivity).  The only highlight is the option to render yourself as a 1-meter tall child and see how everything looks from down there.

reviewText: Really nice environment, a great ad for Ikea. Maybe not the most compelling content in the world for interaction, and framerate was quite slow on my machine w/ 970 GEforce. I would love to see more rooms, or tie them into a video player so that I can watch movies in my Ikea living room. Built with Unreal looks top notch!

reviewText: this is a really cool archetecture visualization project, you really feel like your in a virtual kitchen i wish i could eat the virtual food because it looks like a great place to live. wish that i could walk around the place a little more like it was a real place, but my room for vr is too small. i wish that i could walk through the whole house and stay in dfferent room.\n\nCool demo to show to other people and not make them sick becuause it doesn move ot tilt the camera or anything.

reviewText: Great for showing off the potential of VR. Although the models and physics are pretty basic, your brain will forget about these things and accept it as reality. You often forget you can walk through objects and it feels wrong to do so. It's not hard to imagine something that builds off of this, like distructable models and generative worlds -- stuff that we can already do but just haven't yet for VR.\n\nAlso one thing that's fun to do in this switch heights to small, sit down, then switch heights back to normal. It will assume you are standing up and so the room becomes very small. Like you're in a doll house or something. Very amusing.

reviewText: The best experience currently available for the Vive! I don't know how I ever survived in live without owning this game! I feel like there was a meatball sized hole in my heart before downloading IKEA VR Experience"
date: and this filled it! Thanks IKEA for this once in a lifetime opportunity that I can experience again and again through the power of virtual reality!\n\n12/10 - Best free VR IKEA Simulator"
